body: @jbogard I guess the root cause here is the fact that I made the collection mapper return an expression of a concrete type, to keep that logic inside the mapper. A fix seems difficult and the workaround reasonable.

@lbargaoanu do we have to add the `.ForMember(d=>d.Children, o=>o.UseDestinationValue()) ` for each collection in the DB? Or is there some global setting that we can use for this? Seems like a lot of mappings to adjust...

Are you sure your situation is the same? The whole thing seems pretty weird to me. You can use ForAllPropertMaps or a combination of ForAllMaps and ForAllMembers. The workaround was for this particular case. Usually things just work.
Yes, we are mapping collections from Entity Framework to Lists. Getting a lot of cannot map Hashset to List exceptions and I don't want to add a rule for every child collection...

issue.title: Exceptions since 6.2.1
Some mappings stopped working after upgrade to 6.2.x
issue.body:
After upgrading from 6.1.1 to 6.2.1 we've noticed that some mappings started generating exceptions.

`Unable to cast object of type 'System.Collections.Generic.HashSet`1[DataAccess.EntityB]' to type 'System.Collections.Generic.List`1[DataAccess.EntityB]'`

We're trying to map entity (EntityA) to a DTO (DtoA). That entity has navigation properties (zero-to-many) of type `HashSet<EntityB>` which map to corresponding `IEnumerable<DtoB>` properties on the DTO. It's working fine with `6.1.1`.

The strange thing is the mapping works for some properties but fails for others. I wasn't able to create an isolated gist to replicate the problem.

The same problem exists in 6.2.0

body:
Wow. This seems horrifically excessive. We have hundreds of mappings that we now have to go through and examine each one checking for collections and adding this work-around? 

Is there a fix planned for the near future? After all this worked prior and I'm assuming it can be fixed without the need to temporarily add work-arounds and then remove them later down the line.
@lbargaoanu what was the change that broke this behavior?

https://github.com/AutoMapper/AutoMapper/issues/2397#issuecomment-344011562 If the collection mapper has ISet, it knows it's HashSet, if UseDestinationValue is set, the concrete type doesn't matter. If it's ICollection it must be List. [Here](https://github.com/AutoMapper/AutoMapper/blame/096e58a5385093bd0db727125141731393630d4e/src/AutoMapper/Mappers/Internal/CollectionMapperExpressionFactory.cs#L49). I guess it worked before because the collection mapper didn't decide the concrete type.
This thread has been automatically locked since there has not been any recent activity after it was closed. Please open a new issue for related bugs.
